text:
Chemistry can do some wild tricks with food,
letting you taste in a new way.
Literally, in some cases.

Here’s a party trick to demo your chemistry
prowess.
Depending on the party.

Here’s what you do: before the party gets
rockin, in a different room from the demo

area, take a clove of raw garlic and slice
it in half.

Put these in a garbage bag and tie it up to
contain the smell - we’ll explain later.

Now in a different room that doesn’t smell
like garlic, take off your shoes and socks.
Still with me?

Stick your foot in the bag and rub the garlic
on the bottom of your foot.

Give it about about an hour and you should
start to taste garlic.

Adam: I’m definitely getting waves of garlic
flavor now.

It’s not super strong, but it’s definitely
there.
uh, how are you?
how are you feeling?

Darcy: yeah, there’s sort-of a weird, metallic-ee
flavor, and I am occasionally smelling it,
as it gets stronger in the room.

Adam: Yeah, the odor of garlic is just stinking
the room at this point.
Darcy: yeah, but it’s - it came out of nowhere.

It’s not because you have secret garlic
taste buds on your feet.

It’s because the molecules responsible for
garlic’s smell can penetrate your skin,

get into your blood and travel to your mouth
and nose, where you suddenly start to sense
the taste of garlic.
Chief among those molecules is allicin.
See that oxygen with a double bond to a sulfur?

That looks a lot like the key feature in this
molecule: dimethyl sulfoxide.

DMSO is notoriously good at penetrating our
skin.

It can even carry other chemicals along with
it.

Chemists are extra careful when working with
DMSO, wearing gloves and other protective
equipment.
You know how oil and water don’t mix?

Our skin has layers that repel both oil and
water, which is one reason it’s such a good
barrier.

DMSO and allicin have a little bit of both
kinds of chemical properties: an oxygen for

hydrogen bonding with watery stuff, and hydrocarbon
tails for oily stuff.

They act a little like oil, a little like
water.

So that garlic flavor slips right through
the skin, into your blood, pops up in your
nose and mouth et voilà.

Oh - and we used those garbage bags so it’s
not the smell of garlic in the room that’s
tricking your senses.

You’re actually tasting allicin that went
through your foot.

Give this food chemistry trick a spin and
let us know in the comments how they work
out for you.
But wait!

Tasting with your feet isn’t the only chemistry
food trick out there!

Check out these others on de-foaming beer
and amazing disappearing gum!
Got any other weird food tricks?
Leave them in the comments.

If you haven’t already, make sure to hit
that subscribe button!
Thanks for watching.
